98501.name: Low-Tech Armor & Accessories Reference
98501.description:
User summary:

Commonly utilized low-tech armor and equipment for many different campaign types for easy reference.

98502.name: You Gotta Be Kidding Card Game
98502.description:
Card game version of the board game with same name. You Gotta Be Kidding gets kids and grown-ups thinking, laughing, reasoning and having a blast making goofy decisions and completing the wild "Would You Rather" Challenges. Best of all, kids have fun speaking up for a change, instead of always saying "I don't know." Watch imagination rule and confidence build as kids get comfortable standing up for their choice while laughing the whole time. Players must choose between two difficult scenarios such as: eating a bucket of apple stems or eating 20 banana stems. "Neither" is not permitted as an answer in this card game.

Contents:

160 "Would You Rather" Questions
2 Choice Chips

98503.name: Chessmaster LIVE
98503.description:
User Summary:

This game is a very straightforward version of chess. Players can play either single-player (vs CPU), local multi, or network multi. The CPU is balanced and flexible. Each game will be a little different when playing against the CPU. Sometimes the opponent will be cautious, sometimes aggressive, and sometimes a little of both. Online multi allows for voice and camera integration. The player can either play multi-player in real time, or as "Message Chess" wherein the player trades moves with an opponent over the course of a longer period of time. A notification will great the player each time they sign in to the game, if the opponent has made a move.

There are a few different themes that can be chosen for the board and pieces, but they do not alter the gameplay.

98504.name: Poker Smash
98504.description:
User Summary:

This game is primarily a puzzle game (like Bejeweled) with a bit of a poker theme. The object is to make "poker hands" out of the arrayed cards/gems to remove them from the field. Once removed, new cards drop down to fill their empty spaces. The player also has a few abilities at their disposal. They can slow down time or unleash bombs that clear sections of the board.

There are seven game modes and eleven thematic environments from which to choose. Single player has the normal Adventure mode, as well as Timed Mode and Puzzle Mode. Local multi is split screen, and Online multi allows for up to 5 players to play in tournament style rounds.

98505.name: Orðaspilið: stafaspil
98505.description: From the rules: A deck of 72 cards plus 3 scoring cards and 1 title card. Each card has a letter printed on it (each letter of the alphabet on two cards). The game plays similar to rummy; draw a card from the deck or discarded cards, lay down cards to form a word and discard one card. Each round finishes when the first player plays his last card and then the scores are added up. Game ends when someone has 1000 points (or 100 in the children's variant).

98506.name: Low-Tech Weapons Reference
98506.description:
User summary:

Commonly utilized low-tech weapons for many different campaign types for easy reference.

98507.name: Rocketmen: Axis of Evil
98507.description:
User Summary:

This game was based on a WizKids constructable card game. The video game is in the style of a top-down dual-stick shooter with some RPG elements (similar to Smash TV). The player can create a character that will gain upgrades as the story progresses. Players can choose to play as a male or female; a human, Venusian or Mercurian; and one of the game’s three classes: Warrior, Outcast or Engineer. However, this does not actually alter the gameplay in any discernible fashion.

The gameplay allows for up to 4 players to play co-op. Each player will have a standard weapon, but can pick up short term, powerful weapons that will disappear after a predetermined amount of time. Mission stages have a central goal, as well as secondary goals (gather elements, rescue prisoners, construct new weapons, etc)

98509.name: TiQal
98509.description:
User Summary:

This puzzle game borrows heavily from the TETRIS and Lumines series. TiQal adopts an ancient Mayan theme and reveals bits of trivia between levels. The player controls a sliding bar at the top of the screen and releases pieces in order to form rectangles of similar colored blocks. Completing sets also increases the power bar that will allow the player to unleash a special power that destroys large chunks of the pieces on the board. The two-player multi is co-op and the players work together to create sets to remove the pieces from the board. There are 120 levels 14 different power-ups that can be used.

98510.name: Rocky and Bullwinkle
98510.description:
User Summary:

This game is a party game that compiles 105 microgames. The theme pulls from the classic Rocky and Bullwinkle show by including many of the characters (R&B, Boris and Natasha, Dudley Do-Right, Sherman, Aesop and Son, etc.) The game advances through a series of micro-games, each very basic and only lasting a few seconds. Cereal box tops can be collected and turned in to gain score multipliers and other perks.

Multi-player is a hot-seat style where the controller is passed among the 4 players. Some of the micro-games also make use of the Xbox Vision Camera to some degree.

98511.name: Wits & Wagers
98511.description:
User Summary:

This game is based on the hit board game by North Star Games. The focus of this game is on random trivia. There are more than 700 questions in the game's database. Each time a question is asked, players select their answers from the given list of potential answers. Each player then bids on either their own answer, or another player's if they think that that person actually guessed correctly. This game also integrates the Xbox Vision Camera and Big Button Controller to some extent.

98512.name: More Fantasy Templates
98512.description:
User summary:

Additional races/beings for use with a fantasy campaign.

98513.name: New Mechanic Conventions
98513.description:
From Introduction:

Upcoming Saga Machine releases are likely to follow several new written conventions that make describing the game's mechanics even easier and more concise.

98514.name: Pulp Templates
98514.description:
From Introduction:

The following are a variety of new Template traits for use with Saga Machine in a pulp of pulp-like setting. These Templates represent a variety of common archetypes in the pulp genre.

The Templates listed here use the old trait conventions, as this document was started before the new conventions were published.

98515.name: Random Stats & Card Mechanic
98515.description:
From Introduction:

The Saga Machine core rulebook's Character Generation module provides a couple of ways to determine your character's stats — either through a Template trait or through an array. Some groups, however, prefer a nondeterministic way of generating stats, a way that emulates the uneven distribution of raw ability among the population. Those groups that prefer such a method can use the following system.

98516.name: Combat Lynx
98516.description:
User Summary

In this game, the player operates a Westland Lynx helicopter. Although the Lynx is primarily used as troop transporter and Anti-Submarine Warfare, there are battlefield editions. In this game however, the Combat Lynx uses an enormous array of modern weapons, ranging from several types of guided and unguided rockets, to minefield laying capability and Sidewinder A-A rockets.

In the game, the player flies for an unnamed country with a few helicopter bases. This land is invaded. Tanks and other enemy units slowly make their way towards the bases and when adjacent long enough, will inflict casualties on the personnel ann eventually overrun the base.

The player can prevent this. At start, by laying minefields around the bases. Then, by actively engaging the enemy, using the modern weaponry. And lastly, new personnel can be flown to relieved bases and injured servicemen evacuated.

Since the bases are pretty far out and there are numerous enemies, it is hard to keep all the bases fully staffed and in own possession.

Each time the helicopter touches down on the principle airbase, the player gets the option to load out his chopper, with air to ground weapons, air to air weapons, mines and personnel. The lifting/ loading capacity limits what can be taken. After the loadout screen, the view switches to 3rd person, and the player can take off and perform the actions he deems most necessary.

Although one would be hard pressed to call this game a realistic simulator, it has far too many options, buttons and possibilities to be called arcade.

98517.name: Trystell: Reborn - Background Tables
98517.description:
User summary:

A collection of tables for randomly generating a character background for use with the Trystell: Reborn setting.

98518.name: Trystell: Reborn - Game Master's Guide
98518.description:
From Introduction:

Trystell as a setting dates back 11 years now, to 1998, the very time when Tab Creations grew out of it's predecessor, Tab Comics. Trystell itself is a descendant of the earlier Swords & Arrows comic, but it was really the development of the Trystell setting into a standalone tabletop role-playing game that prompted the setting to take on a life of its own.

Since that time, Trystell has undergone at least three editions, and been converted into a multitude of different systems. Campaigns set in Trystell have been run in a number of cities around the country, and it has even been used for several LARPs.

What you hold in your hands — or read on your computer screen, for those so digitally inclined — is the fourth edition of the Trystell setting, and the second major revision the setting has underwent since its creation. It is also the first and only reboot of the Trystell cannon the setting has received.

We hope you find this work both interesting as a player and useful as a GM's tool. And enjoy

98519.name: Trystell: Reborn - Melanoc: The Core City
98519.description:
From Introduction:

Melanoc is the core city and default campaign location in the Trystell: Reborn setting. As such, it deserves an in-depth look into the details of the city, its people and its workings.

In many ways Melanoc is an unusual city. It is both more cosmopolitan and younger than most cities across Trystell. This, and the fact that Melanoc is a relatively-stable and independent city-state, gives the city a forward-thinking element that attracts many fortune-seekers and free-thinkers from across Trystell.

98520.name: Berserk
98520.description:
The clock is ticking and your time is running out. You need to find just the right peg! Can you do it before you go Berserk? This classic beat-the-clock game combines fun, luck and even a little strategy. Start the clock. Then try to get all the numbers in order from 1 to 20.

Game offers three different skill levels: color matching, color sequencing and counting from 1-20.

Contents:

Game base with integrated timer,
20 Pegs

98521.name: Undead
98521.description:
User summary:

16 new undead for your W.H.A.T Customizable RPG.

98522.name: Professions
98522.description:
From the Foward:

Welcome to W.H.A.T. Professions?, the source book that lets you pick specialized Professional character kits for your W.H.A.T. characters. While the W.H.A.T.? game system is solely based on a customizable point based character generation and advancement engine, Professions allows characters to focus on advancing certain skills and attributes more quickly. A Professional Kit represents that the character is living a certain life style, or at the very least studying elements of that life style.

User summary:

This book describes 7 Professional kits.

98524.name: Bounty Bob Strikes Back!
98524.description:
Bounty Bob Strikes Back! is the sequel to Miner 2049er and was initially released in 1984 for the Atari 8-bit series of computers. It was later ported to the Atari 5200, Commodore 64 and ZX Spectrum in 1985.

Gameplay is similar to Miner 2049er in that the player must inspect every section of 25 mines within a set time while avoiding mutants. One improvement to this sequel is after losing a life, sections on platforms remain covered and destroyed enemies do not reappear, thus making it easier to complete a level.

Source: Wikipedia, "Bounty Bob Strikes Back", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

98525.name: Auf und Davon
98525.description:
from espenlaub.de

"It dawns the morning and the time to dive into the grave. And then the race starts. Head Over Heels is rolled to the right signposts. And then, on the way, they must be extremely careful to not fall into the evil Garlic fog. Which vampire trio go first to the tomb?"

Logic game in which players goes theirs vampires to the crypts.

Player thrown cube and moves his vampire on first free symbol (vertical or horizontal). When a garlic appears, player moves "garlic-clouds" which are blocking opponent move.

98527.description:
The land of Kilforth is a perilous domain filled with nefarious monsters, mysterious Strangers and treacherous Locations, and dominated at its centre by The Sprawl, a huge city where intrepid Heroes begin their journey to fame and fortune. Throughout the land various factions vie for power over each other, such as the supposedly noble Order of the Rose or the terrifying Doom Guard. And presiding over the world outside Kilforth is the ever-present Overlord, Masklaw. Over the coming month, a deadly Gloom will descend upon Kilforth,which the Heroes must Battle through to prove their worth, defeat an Ancient evil, and save the land from darkness.
Gloom of Kilforth is a card game of high fantasy with a Gothic edge, playable in 1-3 hours, where 1-4 players, working individually or together, must take their humble adventurers on a journey through a dark world of magic and peril. They will visit strange places, stranger people and overcome powerful enemies in their mission to discover mysterious artefacts and mystical Spells. Players follow their Hero’s tale from modest beginnings through an epic story to an exciting climactic battle for the fate of the world. Gloom of Kilforth takes about 45 minutes per player to play.

The following is taken from my design journal:

This game has been in development for a long time and has undergone so many permutations in the last six years that I’ve literally ripped it up and started again numerous times. From board game, to miniatures game, to proto-RPG I’ve finally settled on a format I hope will be cost effective and elegant: the card game.
Gloom of Kilforth sees 1-4 players taking a humble adventurer on a journey through a dark world of magic and peril and following their tale from modest beginnings through an epic story to an exciting climactic battle for the fate of the world.
Drawing inspiration from titles we’ve already seen like combat-heavy tactical dungeon crawls (Descent, D&D, etc.), condensed overland adventures concerned either with combat (Runebound) or random encounters (Talisman), games that stretch into story-telling (Tales of the Arabian Nights), cooperative games against insurmountable odds (Arkham Horror, Defenders of the Realm), and tactical adventure card games (Lord of the Rings: The Card Game), I’ve always been looking to design a game that distils the heroic story telling of an in-depth role playing game down into an amount of time that’s playable in an evening. It’s something that many of us crave as we get older and have kids and relationships and jobs and so on which preclude us from throwing all that time away on months of role-playing games.
So whilst I wanted to include all the high fantasy stuff that many of us love, and which in many ways mostly stems from Tolkien’s work, I also tried to develop new techniques of weaving them together to create story-based gameplay.
The two key drivers for the game are the Saga Chapters and Night card decks. The Sagas represent the tales that the heroes will tell as they progress on their journey to fame and fortune, whilst the Night cards are global events that can affect everyone in the Kingdom.

Someone screwed the timeline up

It's 2150. The Earth's recovering from the Great Apocalypse of 1906.

The American wilderness lies below. Beast-haunted wastelands are criss-crossed by the tracks of the freedom-loving Neobedouins. Armoured railroads connect the Emperor's widely scattered domains.

In the walled, fog-shrouded cities, people huddle in forced Victorian squalor, lorded over by the upper classes. The Emperor's clockwork policemen patrol the streets and the ultimate threat of the Change Cage hangs over those who would rebel. Rising from the dockyards, the frigates of the Imperial Air Navy patrol the clouds, hunting pirates and threatening the sky-cities.

You've got an airship. You've got a crew. You've got one of Doctor Calgori's fancy chrononautilus devices. All you need now is a good swig of rum (trust us, you'll need it), and you're ready to set sail on the winds of time and plunder history itself!

Who knows, maybe you'll even screw up the timeline some more?

"With a crew of drunken pilots,
We're the only airship pirates,
We're full of hot air and we're starting to rise,
We're the terror of the skies but a danger to ourselves."

From the music of renowned steampunk band Abney Park

98529.description: Sorry Sliders remade for the movie Cars 2. Build a racetrack and take turns flicking your pawns around the track. Earn four lap counters, then take the final race around the track. Comes with track pieces, barriers, four racers, obstacles, lap counter tokens, a Mater token, a sticker sheet, and a game guide.

98530.name: Trystell: Reborn - Player's Guide
98530.description:
From Introduction:

This book is meant for use with the Saga Machine role-playing system, also available from the Tab Creations Collective. As such, the Saga Machine core rulebook is necessary to make full use of this work.

By default, the Trystell: Reborn setting makes use of four of the five modules found within the main Saga Machine book: the Combat Module, the Environment Module, the Mental Module and the Social Module.

The only module not in use by default is the Character Design Module. While GMs may still use this module for character creation, if they wish, with no ill effects, it's function has been largely replaced by the Lifepath Module introduced later on in this work.

Specific options for the different core modules in use are detailed below:

Baseline Game: Values given in this book will use the Imperial system of measurement, as for better or worse, that is the most commonly used measurement system where the author of this book resides. In addition, the Trystell setting assumes that the GM is making use of the optional Skill trait, with the default skill list provided in the Saga Machine core rulebook.

Combat Module: This text will assume that the GM has chosen to make use of a hex combat grid, and the optional Bleeding rule.

Mental Module: The Trystell setting makes use of different Power Access traits than the example ones given in the Saga Machine rulebook. Most available Power Access traits use the default power use and power strain rules, but are penalized by encumbrance, and access to their granted powers are restricted by Level. Finally, the GM section of this book should have more information on corruption.

Social Module: By default this book assumes that the campaign is making use of the standard wealth rules, without the option for continuing income. Similarly, this work assumes that the GM is not making use of the optional Recognition trait. Using both of these options is quite reasonable, however, and may be and may be quite suited to a campaign centered around the new Core City (Melanoc), and the outlined campaign presented in the GM's section of this book. Finally, Trystell is considered to generally be a Progress Level 5 world, with an average Control Rating of 2 or 3 (albeit that varies a lot with the region).

98531.name: Assault on Darkspyre
98531.description:
From the back cover:

Invade the Tower of an Archmage!

"...and so it stands today, this evil magical fortress. A curse upon the lands of the Kingdom of Kula and a pox upon her peoples. Yet if oracles can be believed, then the time has come for that to change. I spare your treachery against the crown on one condition. You must set foot inside Darkspyre on the morrow and sabotage her defenses. My War priests wish it so, and if the portents are true - and if you are as powerful as you claim to be - then this evil black tower of sorcery shall fall and Malkanai will tremble before the holy army of mighty Kula!

As General Kaga's thundering speech turns to talk of the coming siege, your eye wanders to where the tower of the Archmage Malkanai slashes the sky like an enormous obsidian knife. Memories of fireside tales of the nefarious mage challenge your courage and your stomach begins to wind itself into a tight knot. Of course you are every bit as powerful as you have told the General - but are you and your stalwart companions really strong enough to challenge an Archmage - and in his own home?

98532.name: Shadows Over Sol
98532.description:
From Introduction:

Shadows Over Sol is the latest setting from the Tab Creations Collective. Conceived of late in 2009 as part an initiative to explore the boundaries of what was possible in the Saga Machine system, Shadows Over Sol is the second setting released for the game, and the first to take Saga Machine into the realm of science fiction and outer space.

Space & Horror
Shadows Over Sol borrows themes and elements from the horror genre, in addition to the science fiction genre, and in many ways space is the perfect setting for horror. Space is alien, isolating and quite hostile to human life. It gets characters outside of their comfort zone, separated from all the usual safety nets that they could normally fall back on in society. This isolation forces characters to take matters of survival into their own hands, even if those hands aren't an expert at the task.

Using space as a set-piece for horror provides a variety of tools and features that can be used to further the mood of horror as the player characters struggle to survive: Communications could be cut off. Life support could begin to fail. Sensors could be damaged. Thrusters could be sabotaged, leaving a ship a long, long voyage home. Unexpected things could happen while a character is in hibernation. And, of course, there could be things out there.

Player Characters
Shadows Over Sol is a setting filled with many competing interests, shadowy organizations and secret conspiracies. All of these groups have the need for small bands of agents to covertly do their dirty work, any one of these groups might hire the player characters. Out there in space a thousand things could be happening, all unknown to the population back home — a population that wants to stay fed and comfortable in its ignorance.

Shadows Over Sol by default assumes that player characters are members of one of these freelance teams, working for different organizations. This gives the game master a structure to build sessions around—missions on behalf of one of these entities — and player characters the agency in deciding which missions to take and which organizations they feel comfortable working for. Naturally, however, more dangerous missions come with greater rewards. But even the more innocuous-seeming mission could have unforeseen deadly twists lurking in the darkness of space.

The card decks contained in the Down In Flames - Aces High game will accommodate up to 6 players. However, if you want to play monster air battles, this is the item for you!

98534.name: Trystell Campaign Setting Revised Edition
98534.description:
From Introduction:

Trystell is a world of adventure. Magic, action, danger, combat, treasure, heroes, villains, gold and fame can all be found there. Elements of fantasy such as gnomes, dwarves, elves, minotaur and orcs can be found as well. Yet, in many ways Trystell is a world like our own. Plants, animals, greed, prejudice, honor, humor and deceit can be found within its bounds. Trystell is a setting ideally suited for heroic drama. It is a place where hopes, dreams, fears and ambitions await the eager adventurer. Good battles evil. Heroic adventurers fight sinister villains in epic battles, although sometimes things are a little more gray and the lines between hero an villain become blurred. Good luck in your journey into the fascinating world of Trystell.

How Trystell Differs From Other d20 Games
Trystell has a number of unique elements that distinguish it from other fantasy d20 games. Not only does the world has its own unique flavor, it has a blend of high fantasy, impossible technology and more advanced academic theorems.

In addition to mere setting differences, Trystell also has a number of different variations from the standard d20 game mechanics. The following list is by no means complete, however, it should offer an overview of the most important mechanic chances for the experienced d20 player.

The Trystell setting offers a number of new races, classes and feats. In addition, the Trystell settings overhauls several existing classes.
The Trystell game utilizes a system of determining the contacts and allies of player characters, their reputations in the game world and a system of increasing unarmed AC as a character gains levels.
Characters in the Trystell setting have Vitality and Wound points instead of Hit Points. This provides a more realistic and gritty feel to combat.
The Trystell game utilizes character options called Traits and Flaws. Traits are packages taken at character creation that helps define a characters’ strengths and weaknesses; flaws are kind of like anti-feats that grant characters bonus feats for taking a weakness.
The Trystell setting uses a different system for determining magic. Instead of having set spell slots, a spellcaster has a pool of spell points from which she casts spells.
Player characters in the Trystell setting have a mechanic resource known as Action Points.
There are no true alignments on Trystell. Instead characters have a trait called Allegiance.
Armor on Trystell provides not just a bonus to AC, but a bonus to defense as well.

98535.name: Terror at Camp Waka'Naka
98535.description:

Washington didn't anticipate the deranged psychopath now on the loose. The Thudder is roaming the camp, sledgehammer in hand, ready to bash in the heads of any camp counselors who get in his way. Relive the thrills of a campy B movie with Terror at Camp Waka'Naka, a new adventure in the QAGS horror line.

98536.name: Alien Drug Lords: The Chyropian Connection
98536.description:
From the back of the box:

Load up your laserblasters and re-charge your brain cells for Panther Games' new hair-raising, sci-fi strategy game, Alien Drug Lords.

From the makers of the award winning wargame, Fire-Brigade, comes the ultimate sci-fi game of power, control and drugs.

New Adventurer



Experienced

From the back cover:

Inside this book you will find a wide range of interesting weapons to enhance and Fantasy Role-Playing game.
Each weapon is beautifully illustrated and described in detail.
The Book of Swords will add a note of realism to your game, while helping your players to visualize your world.
Adding your own imagination to this valuable playing aid will make your world truly unique.

98539.description:

The evil forces of Marania attacked the earth. The blue planet was not prepared for a cosmic raid and therefore had to surrender. All soldiers were taken as prisoners .... ALL THE SOLDIERS? Well of course they could not get hold of Captain Cosmose, Hero of Techmania and defeater of the evil Lord Caraz (remember the game TECH by Gainstar)... Alien Legion Features:

4 long levels



Digitised sound effects



High quality graphics

98540.name: Dungeons! Campaign Setting: Rouge's Abode
98540.description:
From the back cover:

Gamer Central Presents

Dungeons! Campaign Setting

For a Game Master there is nothing more helpful than a quick adventure to throw at your players to break your ongoing campaign. A side quest if you will. Something you players won't expect. You hold in your hands that very helpful tool.
This booklet contains all you will need to present that very quick adventure. Grab you group and take a ride.
Happy Gaming!

98541.name: Paradise: A Multi-Genre Setting
98541.description:
From the back cover:

"There's a little town at the egde of the swamps known an Paradise. The people there are what you might call ... rustic. Simple, hard-working people. The salt of the earth. You know ... Morons."
-One-Eyed Jack, on his stay in Paradise

Paradise is the first setting Qik Pak for QAGS, Inside this book, you'll find out how to add Paradise to you existing Fantasy, Sci-Fi, Old West, or Post Apocalypse campaign. Or, you can use the characters and adventures in this Qik Pak as a starting point for an entire game based in the ... err ... rustic town of Paradise!

98543.name: Pyramid (Volume 3, Issue 26 - Dec 2010)
98543.description:
Underwater Adventures

From the publisher:

The ocean is known for its countless riches, waiting to be discovered by adventurous souls. And the key that unlocks the sea's secrets is the "Underwater Adventures" issue of Pyramid, the PDF magazine for roleplayers. This salt-sprayed supplement contains:


"GURPS Fathom Five," a collection of new and updated rules for maneuvering and fighting underwater. How low can you dive? How far can you shoot? The answers are herein.
"The Wreck of the Savoy," a modern-day adventure for GURPS globetrotters. Can the heroes unlock the secrets of Fisherman's Cove and resolve a supernatural conflict that goes back centuries?
"The Yonaguni Monument," a perfectly mysterious place to visit. Whether it's a natural phenomenon, an accomplishment of early humanity, or something stranger, this real-world enigma can form the basis for any number of undersea mysteries.
"The Ocean's Lords," a new undersea species that can appear in all manner of adventures. Do these dangerous dwellers of the deep visit our domain for diplomacy, diagnosis, or destruction?
"The Future of the U-42," an over-the-top adventure that begins with the heroes hired to be part of a reality TV show, and ends with a struggle against Nazis on a long-lost German submarine (making it slightly more realistic than most other reality television).
"The Hotel Nethuns," a generic locale presenting a hotbed of intrigue beneath the icy-cold waves. Espionage and action are always available via room service.


This Pyramid also provides other tidbits that are more fun than finding a sand dollar: Murphy's Rules with Greg Hyland, Steven Marsh's Random Thought Table, and other odds and ends. Don't just get your feet wet; dive into this new issue!

98545.name: Magister (Issue 44 - May 1994)
98545.description:
Magister
Nummer 44 - mei 1994
Issue 44 - May 1994

Cover by Jos Weijmer

98546.name: Hot Dog Run
98546.description:
Available as the toy prize in a children's meal at A&W Restaurants, Hot Dog Run is a simple matching game for 2 to 3 players.

Each player begins with a set number of hot dogs (7 each for a 2-player game; 5 each for 3-player), and then starting with the youngest player (who places their first hot dog near the "start" space on the package) they alternate placing one hot dog at a time so that the symbol on one end matches the symbol on the end of the previously played hot dog. If a player cannot make a match, they must take a new hot dog from the draw pile and then may play it if it matches (if no match is found, that player's turn ends).

The first player to run out of hot dogs wins.

98547.name: GemCraft
98547.description:
User Summary

Gemcraft is a fantasy themed tower defense game where the object is to destroy all the monsters before you run out of mana. Mana is gained over time and by destroying monsters. A monster who makes it past all of your towers is banished for a large sum of mana. If you cannot afford to banish the monster you lose.

Defending is done by building towers and creating gems which cost increasing amounts of mana. Gems come in 8 colors each doing damage and a secondary effect to the monsters it strikes. Secondary effects include Mana gain, poison, stun, slowing, and several others. Gems can be combined to create higher rank gems which deal more damage. Gems can also be thrown as bombs to do area of effect damage.

After each level is completed experience is awarded which allows the player to learn skills. Skills were able to make gems and towers cost less mana, making gems more powerful, or granting starting gems. Old levels can be replayed with higher skills to gain more experience, allowing the harder levels to be completed.

One of the most popular and highly rated games on Kongregate.

98548.name: Fluttabytes
98548.description:
Fluttabyes is a fun, quirky take on a Match 3 game. Easy to pick up and play, yet deeply addictive, the aim of Fluttabyes is to help the butterflies fly away by matching four or more of the same colour. The game is gorgeous and cute, with sunny countryside summer settings in a unique and colourful art style.

Source: The Game Website.

98550.name: Domino Rally
98550.description:
Minon: Everyday Hero, known in Japan as Go! Go! Minon and in North America as Domino Rally (previously under the title Mr. D Goes to Town), is a video game developed by Red Entertainment for Nintendo's Wii console. Its gameplay is similar to the 1998 game No One Can Stop Mr. Domino!.

Source: Wikipedia, "Minon: Everyday Hero", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

98551.name: Fungus
98551.description:
Fungus is an abstract strategy game played on a hex grid by 2 to 4 players. Players take turns placing markers into hex spaces with the ultimate goal of having the fewest number of connected areas on the board and the most markers on the board when the board is completely full.

At the beginning of the game, players take three turns placing a marker anywhere on the board, except along an edge or adjacent to any other marker. After this initial phase, player take turns placing markers, but now they must be adjacent to an enemy marker. During the game, players may have the opportunity to capture enemy markers and place one of their markers in the space or save the markers to alter scores at the end of the game. When the entire board is full of markers, players count their total number of markers on the board and deduct their total number of separate disconnected groups from that amount. The player with the highest total wins.

98552.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Mask of the Archmaester, the fifth monthly Chapter Pack in the Secrets of Oldtown cycle of expansions for A Game of Thrones: The Card Game, introduces 60 cards - three copies each of 20 never-before-seen locations, attachments, characters, events, and plots to aid your A Game of Thrones deckbuilding goals. This Chapter Pack features more Chain attachments as well as more diverse and surprising events and support for the ever-deepening Maester trait.

New characters from George R.R. Martin's A Song of Ice and Fire are introduced into the Living Card Game environment for the first time, including Ser Jon Fossoway and The Mad Mouse. Exciting new versions of existing characters will also enter the fold, including a Rickon Stark that will aid House Stark's deck-searching capabilities. Watch out as sub-themes expand further, including House Dayne's Starfall Cavalry, Iron Fleet Raiders, and more!
98552.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game – Mask of the Archmaester

39953.name: A Game of Thrones: The Card Game

98553.name: SpacePirates
98553.description:
User Summary

The SpacePirates rulebook covers the following topics:


The SpacePirates setting
Sectors
Politics
Technology
Major NPCs
Aliens
Space creatures

Character creation
Action resolution
Space combat
Space ship quirks
GM advice
Introductory adventure Zeitraub (Time Theft).

98554.name: SpaceNinjas
98554.description:
User summary

SpaceNinjas is a sourcebook for SpacePirates. It introduces the Captitalistic Privileged Zone in the New Asia sector and the SpaceNinjas that come from the main planet Kabukicho Prime.

The book includes:

Sector and planet information
Coporations
SpaceNinjas
The dinosaurs of Kabukicho Prime
Adventure Hooks
Two adventures
Rache des Akamachi-Clans (Revenge of the Rache des Akamachi Clan)
Pizza für Jonas Wagner (Pizza for Jonas Wagner). The title stems from a BP TV commercial in which a pizza delivery boy tries to find 'Jonas Wagner' in the BP building and finally arrives in a zero-g environment (Video on myvideo.de).

98555.name: SpaceNinjas Themenbox
98555.description:
User summary

The SpaceNinjas Themenbox (SpaceNinjas Theme Box) is limited edition box for SpacePirates. Only 15 copies have been produced and sold at the Role Play Convention Germany 2011 in Cologne.

The box itself is a pizza box with the cover glued on. Part of the cover is a Post-It note with 'Jonas Wagner' written on it. This is a pun on a BP TV commercial in which a pizza delivery boy tries to find 'Jonas Wagner' in the BP building and finally arrives in a zero-g environment (Video on myvideo.de).

The box contains:

SpacePirates Hardcover version
SpaceNinjas
a color cardstock sector map
a SpacePirates button

98556.name: Dungeonslayers Basisbox

rpgissuearticle.98787: Der Einstieg in neue Welten - Einsteigerfreundliche Spielsysteme

98556.description:
User summary

The Dungeonslayers Basisbox (Dungeonslayers basic box) is the new Dungeonslayers core set.

It contains the core rules, a short GM tutorial with an introductory adventure Die Höhle der Schatten (The Cave of Shadows), maps, character sheets, sample characters and cardstock counters (detailed info see below).

98557.name: Sooty in Wonderland
98557.description:
This is a roll and move game except that you don't roll dice. Instead, the roads on the board have brown lines at intervals and when you move you can only cross one brown line. These lines are diffent distances apart so one turn you may have a decent move, the next a poor one.
The object is to collect 4 special cards - Password Sesame, the Magic Wand, some Oofle Dust and the Key to the Chest. Three Treasure cards are turned face up. When you reach a star symbol on the board that matches one of the three face up cards, you may take one of these cards, then the display is refreshed.
There are Who Knows cards as well which act as Chance cards.
If you collect the four special cards, you must make your way to Sooty's Cave and claim the treasure in the Chest there.
It is suggested that you play a number of games and record the scores to decide a winner.

98558.name: Jack of all Trades

3920.name: KUM-BAK Sports, Toys, & Games, MFG Co. Ltd

98558.description:
The game is played with a pack of 52 cards, made up of 12 tradesmen and a Burglar each using three tools. Players are dealt hands of four cards, and each turn must draw from the top of the deck or from the discard pile. After each draw, the player must discard a card face down. The first player to collect a set of a tradesman and his three tools wins the hand.

The adult version of the game is set up for gambling. Each person antes a coin at the start of each hand. The winner of the hand collects half the pot, but if he has included another tradesman's tool by mistake, he loses a like amount instead. If any player has the Burglar in hand, he must pay a penalty of half the pot - unless he also has the Bobby, in which case he takes the other half of the pot. Similarly, anyone holding one of the Burglar's tools (crowbar, mask or swag bag) pays a penalty of two coins each unless also holding one of the Bobby's tools (handcuffs, lantern or helmet).

There are also rules for young people that make the game a form of "Go Fish".

98559.name: Wordex
98559.description:
52 cards. "The New Card Game of Skill", so says the box.
Each card has a letter. There are more cards for some letters than others. No rules I'm afraid but probably a crossword type game, made to compete with Lexicon, which was a big seller for Waddingtons at that time.

98560.name: Denizens I
98560.description:
From the back of the book:

Every system, every planet needs someone to live, work, and thrive in it. "Denizens I" provides just that. Not just people but, characters, people with something to lose, something to gain, and something that could enrich the lives of your players. "Denizens I" provides two dozen detailed characters for the use as non-player characters and as player characters, for when you don't have the time to toll one up. Inside you will also find pages of information on different culturals, planets, and societies in the form of library data. Let's not forget the ships. "Denizens I", introduces three new ships found in the Foreven Sector. Each ship comes with stats and a full set of deck plans. What are you waiting for? It's time to start really exploring the unknown.

98563.name: Pok-A-Dice
98563.description:
A great party game of chance. Everybody wins--not always, but sometimes! Friendly fun to liven up a party.

Players bet their chips on the Pok-e-dice layout: one each on "Low Hand", "High Hand", "Low Total", "High Total", "Pot".

Players roll the dice and selects the poker combinations. place their chips on the layout and after everybody has taken their turn, the player with the highest score wins all the chips in the "Pot"

98564.name: Postmodern: Talent Tree Compendium
98564.description:
From publisher blurb:

Postmodern: Talent Tree Compendium offers a wide variety of talents for the existing modern base classes (Charismatic, Dedicated, Fast, Smart, Strong and Tough). The 58 compiled Talent Trees include Bulletproof, Foe Hammer, God of Gamblers, Instinctive Response and many more...

Many of these talents are completely new, while others are based on pre-existing Modern class abilities or have been pulled from the wealth of open game content published for other d20 system games. Whatever their origins, all have been carefully re-examined (and in most cases changed) to improve their game balance, clarity, interaction with other abilities, and overall coolness factor-- as a result, D20 Postmodern Talent Tree Compendium makes your modern characters more colorful, exciting, and fun to play than ever before.

98565.name: Postmodern: The Versatile Hero
98565.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Versatile hero is the proverbial jack-of-all-trades. If you've ever imagined a character concept so unique and original that you couldn't quite fit it into one of the pre-existing base classes, the Versatile hero is for you! Never settle for "almost" the character you wanted to make again!

Postmodern Versatile Hero includes:

A new base class for Modern d20 games, one that does not depend on any specific ability score!
Twelve new talent trees (two for each existing base class), comprised of both new talents and abilities from various OGC sources, edited for game balance and consistency -- all usable with the Versatile hero, since the Versatile hero can use talents from any class!
A uniquely integrated "Development Point" mechanic, allowing you to customize all aspects of your modern d20 character, from base attack bonus to class skills to talent trees!

98566.name: Postmodern: Traits and Flaws
98566.description:
From publisher blurb:

Postmodern: Traits and Flaws offers a complete system of self-balancing character traits. These traits are designed to flesh out aspects of your character, such as personality, background, or even physique. Traits can serve as an interesting starting point for roleplaying, reminding players of their character's most prominent strengths and weaknesses. Suggestions for roleplaying opportunities are given throughout. Character traits include coldly logical, strange luck, preternaturally sensitive and many more...

Flaws exist as a sort of anti-feat. Whereas a feat enables a character to be better than normal at performing a task (or even to do something that normal characters can't), a flaw restricts a character's capabilities or imposes a penalty of some sort. Character flaws include criminal record, manchurian candidate, tracking implant and many more...

As a bonus, Postmodern: Traits and Flaws includes a system of character disadvantages. These disadvantages are designed to inject dramatic situations into a character's day-to-day life. These disadvantages may stem from the character's background or some persistent element of the character's personality or daily experiences. Character disadvantages include amnesia, personal code, guilt and many more...

Postmodern Traits and Flaws includes:

Five categories of traits and flaws; mundane, conspiracy, occult, psionic and supernatural.
Forty character traits.
Twenty-six flaws.
Fifteen disadvantages.

98567.name: Postmodern: Traits and Flaws 2
98567.description:
From publisher blurb:

Postmodern: Traits and Flaws 2 expands on the system of character traits and flaws presented in the first Postmodern: Traits and Flaws. These traits are designed to flesh out aspects of your character, such as personality, background, or even physique. Traits can serve as an interesting starting point for roleplaying, reminding players of their character's most prominent strengths and weaknesses. Flaws exist as a sort of anti-feat. Whereas a feat enables a character to be better than normal at performing a task (or even to do something that normal characters can't), a flaw restricts a character's capabilities or imposes a penalty of some sort.

Postmodern Traits and Flaws 2 includes:

Five categories of traits and flaws; mundane, conspiracy, occult, psionic and supernatural.
Thirteen new character traits.
Ten new flaws.




Note: The original [Traits and Flaws] may be required to utilize these new traits and flaws fully.

98568.name: Postmodern: Iconic Combat Feats
98568.description:
From publisher blurb:

Have more fun in combat-- with this pdf of 129 feats for your Modern d20 game!

Postmodern: Iconic Combat Feats expands on the core combat feats from the d20 Modern roleplaying game-- building on such favorites as Power Attack, Point Blank Shot, Bull Rush, Combat Expertise, and so on-- to present 108 dynamic new feats guaranteed to give new life to Modern games by taking the tactics and abilities of the feats you know and creating a whole family of complimentary feats for each one. The strategies and mechanics you thought you knew become more applicable and more useful as your game progresses into higher levels, making Modern d20 characters more potent and interesting than ever before.

Beyond those 108 iconic feats, 14 unarmed fighting style feats add granularity and flavor to the d20 Modern roleplaying game's generic martial arts material, while potent new applications for action points and 7 action point related feats further expand the possibilities for dramatic action and cinematic excitement in any Modern d20 game.

98569.name: Postmodern: Set-Pieces
98569.description:
From publisher blurb:

There is far more to an exciting and cinematic fight scene than endless blacktop and nondescript rooms. Fights can occur in all kinds of places - in the narrow, rain-slick alleyways of a city; on the deck of a ship pitching in a storm; on the hard icy floor of a hockey rink; waist-deep in the thick muck of a Florida swamp; or, even in the strange landscape of some alien world.

Set-pieces provides several ways to define the battlefield including Slipperiness, Slope, Narrow Footing, Obstacles, and Glare. Also presented are thirteen new Props you can use to spice up combat.

98570.name: Postmodern: Skill Groups
98570.description:
From publisher blurb:

An alternate method of selecting skills for your Modern d20 character.

Skill groups are a way of representing the interrelated nature of certain skills. The fact is, realistically, most characters who can move silently should also know how to hide, and people who can ride an animal are usually good at handling animals as well. There are exceptions, of course--it seems logical that characters with Listen would also have ranks of Spot, but a blind character would have no Spot ranks despite a high Listen--but just as the rules allow this specificity, there ought to be a means of representing the fact that training in some skills gives you a level of competence in others or that many people train in multiple related skills at once.

POSTMODERN: Skill Groups presents an alternate system of skill selection that gives your character access to skill groups derived from his or her classes, occupation, and advanced classes.

Additionally, this pdf presents a system for Skill Challenges. Skill challenges reflect an expert's ability to perform routine tasks with superior grace and efficiency. They also allow you to attempt heroic deeds otherwise unavailable to you by making already difficult skill checks even harder. With a bit of luck, skill, and good planning, you can achieve the impossible.

98571.name: Postmodern: Fantastic Classes
98571.description:
From publisher blurb:

Each of the iconic fantasy classes has been stripped down to its barest essence and then reconstructed according to the structure of the basic Modern classes. Each is reconstituted in such a way that an individual player could use each class in its classic form, if they wished, but can also take advantage of the adaptability of Modern base classes to create a character who fills the class’s archetypal role in new and interesting ways. Also the classes can be used as advanced classes and can be used with or without their arcane and psionic elements.

The fantasy classes' core abilities have been stripped out and are presented as talent trees. This provides players and GMs alike with more opportunities to incorporate arcane, divine, and psionic abilities in their game.

Also presented are guidelines, along with several Plus feats, for replicating the progression of many of the original fantasy classes and prestige classes.

Note: BFG's [Talent Tree Compendium] may be required to make complete use of some of these classes, and a handful of feats are referenced from BFG's [Iconic Combat Feats].

When the governor of Isla Aether approaches you with a treasure map pointing the way to ancient ruins filled with valuable technology, it seems like any easy job. 98576.name: The Zeotis
98576.description:
From Introduction:

The Zeotis, as a setting, is the Tab Creations Collective's oldest. It dates back to the very beginnings of Tab Creations, back to 1993, when Tab Creations' focus was still primarily on comics and not on role-playing games.

In those early days the setting began with a handful of superheroes created by the various members of the Collective , and then a variety of supervillains were created to combat them. From there the setting began to grow, remaining Tab Creations' biggest focus until 1998, when work began on the Swords & Arrows Role-Playing Game and the Trystell fantasy setting. Even then it was intended that the Zeotis would get its own roleplaying game using the same system. Plans were drawn up, yet they never came to fruition, and the Zeotis slowly fell by the wayside. Until now!

Since those early days the Zeotis setting has undergone at least two major revisions, as well as major expansions and oversight to add some degree of continuity and internal consistency to the setting —although it is a supers setting, and in the supers genre, bold characters and larger-than-life personalities loom larger than mere setting verisimilitude.

So here it is. Welcome to the first official release of the the Zeotis setting in a role-playing game format. Designed for use with our Saga Machine rules system, this booklet — along with the Saga Machine core rulebook — should contain everything you need to write and run your own campaign set in the Zeotis universe.

So go find some players, come up with some colorful concepts and get your game stared. We hope you enjoy the ride.


Themes & Assumptions

There is something of a paradox at the core of any supers role-playing game setting: Supers settings by long-standing tradition focus first and foremost on the lives, powers and personalities of their star characters. In any individual title, the themes and personalities of that title take precedent over any continuity and themes for the supers world as a whole. And in a supers game, that's perhaps as it should be.

Because of that, supers role-playing settings benefit from being somewhat “generic,” so as to allow player characters and their personal themes to easily assume that title role and limelight in the setting. It should be noted then that while this booklet details a number of cannon elements to the Zeotis setting, and a number of signature characters, they are meant to be used as background by the GM. While it might be interesting to have one of the cannon superheroes guest star for the session — or even be a sympathetic antagonistic for a session — these signature characters should not overshadow the player characters of the campaign, and at the end of the day, should retire back to somewhere in the background.

All things being equal, though, the Zeotis setting was written to have some underlying sets of assumptions to it. There are a wide range of supers stories out there, and the basic themes and assumptions of supers universes has changed many times over their long history.

That said, the Zeotis setting has something of a "Bronze Age" feel to it. Heroes are larger than life, although not as absurdly powerful as the heroes of the "Silver Age." Darker social issues and circumstances are not shied away from, yet heroes are generally still recognizably heroes—with their bright costumes and their altruistic agendas — not really the brooding anti-heroes of the "Iron Age."

If these terms for the different eras of supers confuse you, don't worry. They get described in detail later in this booklet.


Modules

Naturally, this booklet is meant for use with the Saga Machine role-playing system. And as a Saga Machine product, a variety of optional modules are used to create the feel of a supers setting. Which modules and options are in use are detailed below.

Supers Module: A new module presented in this booklet, the Super Module details a variety of new rules meant to emulate the supers genre, as well as tweaking the options used by the other modules.
Character Design Module: The Character Design Module is fully in use for the Zeotis setting, albeit with a number of new options presented by the Supers Module. Of note are the various supers arrays for generating stats, and the bid system for super power limitations.
Combat Module: The combat module is, of course, in use, as spectacular combats are a staple of the genre. Of the Combat Module options, both the Hit Points variant and abstract movement are turned on.
Environment Module: The Environment Module presented in the Saga Machine core rulebook is not used. It is largely replaced by the Supers Module.
Mental Module: The Mental Module is in use, although a new variant on the usual Focus and Composure Track in in use, and presented as part of the Super Module.
Social Module: While the Abstract Wealth system is poached by the Supers Module, the Social Module is not otherwise in use with the Zeotis setting.

98577.name: Casus Belli (Issue 17 - Oct 1983)
98577.description:
User Summary:
